ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned multivariable concepts.
I learned math
Gained a strong understanding of multivariable calculus and many of the fundamental theorems in calculus
Completed my knowledge and study of calculus
multivariant calculus

In this MATH 120 section (taught by Professor Ian Adelstein), I learned a lot related to multivariable & vector calculus, as well as functions of geometry within three-dimensional spaces. I now have a great grasp on scalar and vector functions, in-depth multivariable integrals of three-dimensional surface area and volume, and different ways to approach and go about different problems.
The class teaches multivariable calculus (Calc III), which you take after Calc II or AP Calculus BC

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked how the course included pre class videos to engage in the content before hand. However, I would have liked if these videos were a little shorter.
Hate break out rooms. Awkward and jam board is hard to use. Not good use of time. The videos beforehand is really useful. I like doing example problems as a class especially when class size is small.
The recorded lessons were very useful in gaining the foundational understanding of the material and there was always lots of practice problems that could be done

The strength is that there are a lot of resources available to learn the material outside of lecture. The TAs were extremely helpful, so were the review sessions. One weakness is that sometimes that homework was not very applicable to what was being tested. Also, I did not love continuing with new material before being tested on a midterm. I would have much rather do some type of review in class rather than get new concepts confused, or avoid them in order to not become confused, which then impacted me later in the course. That being said, the course was very well structured.

weaknesses: too much out-of-class work; between the long, weekly psets and the pre class videos, the work was just too much
strengths: many resources

One strength of MATH 120 overall would be the material covered in the class. Another strength would be the resources available to learn. The pre-recorded lecture videos and the peer tutor sessions (both available to all MATH 120 students) were both quite helpful!
One weakness of MATH 120 overall might be the length and timing of some of the weekly homework Problem Sets (typically due each Friday) that are assigned to all sections. Around half the time the Problem Sets are often a bit long, but the other half of the time they're of a more-reasonable length. However, it's sometimes a bit challenging to get some of the longer Problem Sets done for Friday while also juggling other classes' end-of-the-week deadlines as well.

The main strength of this course is the small class sizes of each Math 120 section. Since each class only has around 10-15 students, the professor can spend more time answering questions and interacting with the students, which gives us many opportunities to ask questions and participate in the lecture, which is nice compared to the often unengaging large lecture classes of other STEM classes. In addition, the peer tutors in office hours are helpful with test prep and homework. There aren't any major weaknesses with this course

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked doing polls on zoom. They were useful.
Recording the lectures.
virtual whiteboard was good

The pre-recorded lecture videos (on the Canvas page for all MATH 120 students) made learning accessible in a virtual learning environment. Professor Adelstein making each day's slides available to the section  (as well as recording each class and making the recording available to the section)  was also quite helpful!
I hope they keep the virtual MATH 120 peer tutor sessions as well. It's a lot easier to be able to go to a virtual peer tutor session than to run to a physical one! :)

The small classes of the live lectures made possible lots of interaction between the instructor and students, which made class much more engaging and allowed us to ask more questions directly in-class, which was great. In-class activities like breakout rooms and polls were also good for testing our knowledge and getting to know our classmates, and I think they contributed positively to my course experience. Virtual office hours also worked pretty well, and the ULAs were all pretty responsive to questions.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to another student, especially if they need it for a requirement. It is not as bad as people make it out to be.
Yes if they need math
If you would like to complete your knowledge of calculus then yes
I would if they need the course. If they simply need a quantitative credit, there may be other courses that are less stressful.
No, however, it is a necessary prerequisite for many majors and classes

Yes; if you're taking MATH 120, Professor Adelstein does a really good job teaching the course (combined with watching the pre-recorded lecture videos and/or reading the associated textbook chapters). I learned a lot related to multivariable & vector calculus, as well as functions of geometry within three-dimensional spaces. I now have a great grasp on scalar and vector functions, in-depth multivariable integrals of three-dimensional surface area and volume, and different ways to approach and go about different problems.
Also, if you're taking MATH 120: definitely go to some of the weekly peer tutor sessions as well!

Yes! If you need multivariable calculus as a prerequisite for any of your classes, then go ahead and take MATH 120. The class isn't too difficult and you learn the material pretty well in the course. However, experiences with the course might vary depending on which instructor you get; I had Professor Adelstein and he was great (10/10 would recommend)

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Watch videos before hand and then go to lecture/seminar
Recorded lectures that could be watched in place of textbook readings along with live virtual lectures/discussions two times a week
Pre-class recorded lectures.
Office hours, ximera
live virtual office hours, peer tutoring
Pre-recorded lecture videos to be watched before each class, and a live virtual class as well
